channel.title: Callback methods and lamda expressions on Programming project 2023-24
channel.description: Recent content in Callback methods and lamda expressions on Programming project 2023-24

item.title: Pure function
item.description: Pure function # Side effects # Definition. A method has side effects if it modifies resources (variable, object, array, etc.) that are accessible outside of its scope. Definition # A pure function is a method that intuitively behaves like a mathematical function. More precisely: Definition. A pure function is a method that: returns a value, returns the same value if called twice with the same arguments, and has no side-effect.

item.title: Anonymous method
item.description: Anonymous method # An anonymous method is a method without a name. Illustration # The two following Java methods only differ by their name: int square(int x){ return x * x; } int toThePowerOfTwo(int x){ return x * x; } So in a sense, these two methods are the same method. An anonymous method simply abstracts away from the name of the method. For instance, in Java, the two methods above could be described with the following lambda expression:

item.title: Type of a method
item.description: Type of a method # Terminology. The type (a.k.a. signature) of a method consists of: the type(s) of its argument(s), and its return type. Notation. The type of a method is sometimes described analogously to the type of a mathematical function. For instance, consider the following Java method square: int square(int x){ return x * x; } This method takes as input an int, and returns an int. In other words, this is a function with domain int and codomain int.

item.title: Callback method
item.description: Callback method # When a method takes another method as argument, the latter is a callback method. Anonymous methods are often used as callback methods. in Java # A callback method in Java can be: a lambda expression, or a method reference. Running example # Example. The two following Java methods have the same structure: both modify each unit in the input array. void boostUnits(Unit[] units){ for(Unit unit: units){ unit.

item.title: Lambda expression
item.description: Lambda expression # In certain programming languages like Java, C#, C++ or JavaScript, the term lambda expression (sometimes called closure expression) is used to denote an anonymous method with a certain syntax. The term is a (loose) reference to lambda calculus, a model of computation exclusively based on function composition and application. Syntax in Java # A Java method <ReturnType> myMethod (<Type 1> <argument 1>, .., <Type n> <argument n>){ <Body> } can be written anonymously as the lambda expression:

item.title: Captured variables
item.description: Captured variables # In practice, lambda expressions are often used to represent pure functions. Some languages (like Java, JavaScript, C++, etc) restrict (or allow the user to restrict) the usage of lambda expressions, so that they lean towards pure functions. Terminology. Some programming languages allow a lambda expression to use variables that: are declared outside of the lambda expression’s body, and are not arguments of the lambda expression. This type of lambda expression is called a capturing lambda, and these variable are said to be captured.

item.title: Java stream pipeline
item.description: Java stream pipeline # A Java stream is a sequence of objects. When it is finite, a stream can be viewed of as a list with limitations: a stream can only be iterated over, from left to right, and only once (this is called consuming a stream). Stream computations are specified as a pipeline, which consists of: a source (e.g. a collection or an I/O channel), zero or more intermediate operations (e.
